The '''1959 anti-American riots in Panama''' happened during the celebration of [[Separation of Panama from Colombia|Panamanian independence]] on November 3, 1959. Demonstrations started that day as Panamanians were influenced by former foreign minister [[Aquilino Boyd]], who threatened a "peaceful invasion" of the American-controlled [[Panama Canal Zone]], to raise the flag of the republic there as tangible evidence of Panama's sovereignty over the territory.<ref name="LoC">{{cite book |editor1-last=Meditz |editor1-first=Sandra W. |editor2-last=Hanratty |editor2-first=Dennis M. |title=Panama : A Country Study |date=1989 |publisher=Library of Congress |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/88600486/ |language=en}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
Fearful that Panamanian mobs might actually force entry into the Canal Zone, the [[United States]] called out its troops. Several hundred Panamanians crossed barbed-wire restraints and clashed with Canal Zone police and troops. A second wave of Panamanian citizens was repulsed by the [[Panamanian National Guard]], supported by American troops.<ref>https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19591103.2.10</ref> Extensive and violent disorder followed. A mob smashed the windows of the United States Information Agency library. The United States flag was torn from the ambassador's residence and trampled, and the U.S. embassy was attacked. Stones were thrown against the troops, who were dispersed by [[tear gas]]. Three American troops were injured, whilst two student protesters were arrested.<ref name="LoC"/><ref>https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19591103.2.10</ref>
Aware that public hostility was getting out of hand, political leaders attempted to regain control over their followers but were unsuccessful. Relations between the two governments were severely strained. United States authorities erected a fence on the border of the Canal Zone, and United States citizens residing in the Canal Zone observed a voluntary boycott of Panamanian merchants, who traditionally depended heavily on these patrons.<ref name="LoC"/><ref>https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/panama-canal-flag-riots</ref>
Tension were already stoked before amid the discontent over the Canal Zone. In May 1958 students demonstrating against the United States clashed with the National Guard, and nine peopled died in the violence.<ref name="LoC"/> On September 17, 1960, American President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] attempted to defuse the issue by letting the [[Flag of Panama]] fly alongside the [[Flag of the United States|Stars and Stripes]] of the U.S. inside the Canal Zone. After the events of 1959, violence occurred [[Martyrs' Day (Panama)|again in 1964]].<ref>https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/panama-canal-flag-riots</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = AngelHack | logo = AngelHack logo.png | founders = Greg Gopman, Krystyl Baldwin and Sabeen Ali | founded = 2011 | industry = [[Hackathons]] and [[Innovation Management]] | location = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | website = {{url|https://angelhack.com}} }} '''AngelHack''' is a global [[hackathon]] and innovation organization. It originated in San Francisco and has since expanded to over 50 cities with over 100,000 developers.
AngelHack hosts an annual global hackathon competition where entrants compete to build, test, and launch new software solutions over the course of a weekend. AngelHack is also the creator of [https://angelhack.com/hackcelerator/ HACKcelerator] and [https://globaldemoday.io/ Global Demo Day.]
AngelHack facilitates corporate hackathons and has partnered with organizations such as Comcast-NBC Universal, Hasbro, IBM, Nationwide and Discover to run themed events designed to prototype ideas.
AngelHack's community consists of approximately 160,000 members. Currently, it is a female-owned, female-majority company run by co-founder and CEO Sabeen Ali.
==Background== AngelHack was founded in September 2011 by Greg Gopman and Krystyl Baldwin. In late 2011, Greg Osuri and Sabeen Ali joined as co-founders. Sabeen is the current CEO and remaining co-founder at AngelHack.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/angelhack#section-overview|title=AngelHack Crunchbase|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Code For A Cause is a subsequent nonprofit organization that was founded in 2013 by Sabeen Ali and AngelHack after seeing an opportunity to create a dialogue about the equality gap in technology.
==AngelHack Series==
=== HACKcelerator === HACKcelerator is a pre-accelerator program that provides mentorship to entrepreneurs and showcases companies to investors. AngelHack is the highest valued pre-accelerator in the industry with a startup portfolio valuation of $75M and acquisitions from tech leaders such as Google and BOX. Notable HACKcelerator teams include WeFunder, Microryza, Waigo Translate, SlickLogin and Appetas, Osper, and AtumSoft.
=== Global Demo Day === After winning local AngelHack hackathons and completing the 12-week pre-accelerator program, startups are given the opportunity to present their ideas at Global Demo Day in San Francisco. This event allows the winning startups to pitch their prototypes and business plans to potential investors and industry experts while competing for prizes.
== Corporate Innovation == AngelHack has worked with over 100 companies across the world, building out innovation programs, developer marketing initiatives, and running internal and external hackathons. Notable corporate hackathons include the official [https://us.money2020.com/hackathon hackathon] of the yearly Money20/20 FinTech conference in Las Vegas, a [https://eoshackathon.io/ global hackathon series] targeting blockchain developers with [[EOS.IO|EOS]], and a massive 15-city hackathon series with MasterCard in 2015, [https://newsroom.mastercard.com/press-releases/mastercard-masters-of-code-hackathon-series-to-crown-100000-global-winner/ Masters of Cod]e.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Bandung 2017.jpg|thumb|Exhibition logo]] The '''BANDUNG 2017 Specialized World Stamp Exhibition''' was an international [[stamp exhibition]] held 3–7 August 2017 at the Trans Studio Convention Center in [[Bandung]], Indonesia. The exhibition was granted patronage from the [[Fédération Internationale de Philatélie]] (FIP).<ref name="f-i-p">{{cite web|url=http://www.f-i-p.ch/exhibitions/results/|title=Results | Fédération Internationale de Philatélie|website=f-i-p.ch|date=12 December 2017|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
There were 455 exhibits.<ref name="cendananews">{{cite web|url=https://www.cendananews.com/2017/08/buku-pak-harto-dalam-perangko-sabet-medali-dalam-world-stamp-exhibition-2017-di-bandung.html|author=Thowaf Zhuharon|title=Buku “Jejak Pak Harto di Atas Perangko” Sabet Medali dalam World Stamp Exhibition 2017 di Bandung|website=Cendana News|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
==Palmares== The Grand Prix awards went to the following exhibits:<ref name="grandprixclub">{{cite web|url=http://www.grandprixclub.net/Latest-News.php|website=grandprixclub.net|title=Grand Prix Club|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
The Grand Prix International went to Ding Jinsong (China) for ‘The 1897 Red Revenue Surcharges of China‘ (97 points).
The Grand Prix National went to Indra Kusuma (Indonesia) for ‘Repoeblik Indonesia 1945–1949, Local Issued Stamps during Independent War in Java Island‘ (96 points).
==References== {{reflist}}

<!-- Write your article below this line --> {{Infobox recurring event | name = Beyond The Border Wales International Storytelling Festival | logo = BtB small logo.png | logo_size = 220px | location = [[St Donat's Castle]], [[Wales]] | years_active = 1993 - Present | dates = Summer 2018 [Dates TBC] | genre = [[Storytelling]] / [[Spoken Word]] / [[World Music]] | website = {{URL|http://www.beyondtheborder.com/}} }}
'''Beyond The Border Wales International Storytelling Festival''' is a Wales-based international arts festival dedicated to celebrating the retelling of the world’s traditional stories.
Begun in 1993, the festival is held every other year over the first weekend in July in the grounds of [[St Donat's Castle]], on the Heritage Coast of the [[Vale of Glamorgan]].<ref name="literaryfestivals">{{cite web|url=http://www.literaryfestivals.co.uk/beyond_the_border.html|title=Beyond the Border - Wales International Storytelling Festival. Literary Festivals UK. Dates, details of hundreds of Literary Festivals|publisher=literaryfestivals.co.uk|accessdate=2015-11-01}}</ref> Along with performances of world myth, legend and folktale, the festival features music, poetry, cinema, dance, theatre and puppetry, together with world food stalls, workshops, Craft Market, bookshops and the Beyond The Border Real Ale Bar.
The 2014 festival involved over 100 different performances taking place in 9 different venues throughout the gardens of St Donat's Castle, including the Tythe Barn Theatre and the 14th Century Bradenstoke Hall of [[St Donat's Castle]], and attracted over 2000 people of all ages, drawn from across the UK and abroad. The festival is supported among others by [[Arts Council of Wales]],<ref name="artswales">{{cite web|url=http://www.artswales.org.uk/63914|title=Arts Council of Wales | Beyond the Border Storytelling Festival|publisher=artswales.org.uk|accessdate=2015-11-01}}</ref> and has been awarded Major Events Status by the Welsh Government.
In addition to the biennial festival weekend, Beyond The Border runs an active year-round programme of storytelling events and community activities, aimed at raising awareness of the art of performance storytelling and the world’s common heritage of traditional stories.

[[File:Curzon line en.svg|thumb|right|300px|Bug River property lies to the east of the Curzon Line-based part of the modern Polish border]] The '''Bug River property''' ({{lang-pl|Mienie zabużańskie}}, "Trans-Bug property") is property which was within the territory of the [[interbellum]] Poland ([[Second Polish Republic]]) and was abandoned by Polish owners after 1945. it was abandoned when the territory was no longer inside of [[Poland]]. The name refers to [[Bug River]] because the Bug is a major part of the new eastern boundary of Poland (roughly based on the [[Curzon Line]]), separating the so-called [[Eastern Borderlands]] from the rest of the former Polish territory. The Bug River property is located within the states of [[Belarus]], [[Lithuania]], and [[Ukraine]].[http://www.msp.gov.pl/en/restitution/bug-river-claims/118,Bug-river-claims.html "Bug River claims"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419204516/http://www.msp.gov.pl/en/restitution/bug-river-claims/118%2CBug-river-claims.html |date=April 19, 2015 }}, [[Ministry of State Treasury (Poland)|Ministry of Treasury of the Republic of Poland]] (retrieved April 19, 2015) The claims for compensation for this lost property are known as the '''Bug River claims'''. The agreements between the USSR and the interim Polish government ([[Government of National Unity]]) mostly concerned the evacuation of the population, and did not set out in any detail rules for compensation for owners of abandoned property. The laws of the [[Communist Poland]] had a number of provisions concerning the issues related to agricultural land and unmovable property. In modern Poland, the act of December 12, 2003, by offsetting the value of the property abandoned abroad against sales price or fees for perpetual use is regarded as a base for state compensation to Polish citizens for the value of the abandoned property. As of February 29, 2003, 82,000 applications for compensation were submitted, with total estimate value over 10,500 million [[Polish złoty|PLN]]. Due to unsatisfactory handling of the issue, it was raised before the Constitutional Tribunal (2002 proceedings ''Regional Protection of Human Rights'', Volume 1, 2013, {{ISBN|0199941521}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=HAfFyRlCYjUC&pg=PA862 p.862]). In 2004 the issue was considered by the [[European Court for Human Rights]] (pilot case: ''Broniowski v. Poland''[http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx?i=001-70326 Case ''Broniowski v. Poland''], [[HUDOC]] database). The Court found
a systemic problem connected with the malfunctioning of domestic legislation and practice caused by the failure to set up an effective mechanism to implement the "right to credit" of Bug River claimants ... with the consequence that not only the applicant in this particular case but also a whole class of individuals had been or were still denied the peaceful enjoyment of their possessions.
The Court noted that the issue was not satisfactorily resolved for some 80,000 claims.''The Individual in the International Legal System: Continuity and Change in International Law'', 2011, {{ISBN|1139499971}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=LF7k-bnyMMoC&pg=PA333 p. 333] Further decrees on the implementation of the right for compensation include: *Decree of July 8, 2005 "O realizacji prawa do rekompensaty z tytułu pozostawienia nieruchomości poza obecnymi granicami Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej" (Dz. U. z 2005r. Nr 169 poz. 1418). *Decree of September 8, 2006 "O zmianie ustawy o realizacji prawa do rekompensaty z tytułu pozostawienia nieruchomości poza obecnymi granicami Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej oraz niektórych innych ustaw" (Dz. U. 2006r.Nr 195 poz. 1437). In February 2014 President [[Bronisław Komorowski]] signed a decree to further update the regulations related to compensation for Bug River property. In particular, the decree removed a number of restrictions to the right for the compensation.[http://wyborcza.pl/1,91446,15390132,Prezydent_podpisal_ustawe_ws__rekompensat_za_mienie.html "Prezydent podpisał ustawę ws. rekompensat za mienie zabużańskie"] In doing so, it addressed the issues raised before the Constitutional Tribunal and the ECHR on the subject.''International Law and Domestic Legal Systems: Incorporation, Transformation, and Persuasion'', 2011, {{ISBN|0191029769}}, Chapter "Poland" by Anna Wyrozumska, [https://books.google.com/books?id=9aHFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA479 p. 479] Recently, due to the aspirations of Ukraine to join the [[European Union]], Polish society raised an issue whether Ukraine will be willing to share the burden of the compensation.[http://pl.sputniknews.com/opinie/20150417/264893.html "Zwrot Kresów: Czy Ukraina zapłaci wystawione rachunki?"] Reportedly, Lithuania has been very reluctantly handling the claims of Poles for compensation/restitution.[http://kurierwilenski.lt/2013/12/06/nic-co-polskie-polakom-na-litwie/ "Nic co polskie Polakom na Litwie"] ("Nothing Polish to be Returned to Poles in Lithuania"), ''[[Kurier Wilenski]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Polish law]] [[Category:Aftermath of World War II]] [[Category:Property law]] [[Category:Human rights in Poland]] [[Category:Poland–Soviet Union relations]]

'''Children in emergencies and conflicts''' constitutes the effects of situations that pose detrimental risks to the [[Child Health|health]], safety, and well-being of children. There are many different kinds of conflicts and emergencies, for example, violence, armed conflicts, [[war]], [[natural disaster]]s, etc. Approximately 13 million children are displaced by [[armed conflicts]] and [[violence]] around the world.<ref name=":0">UNICEF. 2010. ''The State of the World’s Children Report, Special Edition''. New York, UNICEF.</ref> Where violent conflicts are the norm, the lives of young children are significantly disrupted and their families have great difficulty in offering the sensitive and consistent care that young children need for their healthy development.<ref name=":0" /> Studies on the effect of emergencies and conflict on the [[Physical health|physical]] and [[mental health]] of children between birth and 8 years old show that where the disaster is natural, the rate of [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|PTSD]] occurs in anywhere from 3 to 87 per cent of affected children.<ref>Garrison, C. Z., Bryant, E. S., Addy, C. L., Spurrier, P. G., Freedy, J. R., and Kilpatrick, D. G. 1995. Posttraumatic stress disorder in adolescents after Hurricane Andrew. ''Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry'', Vol. 34, pp. 1193-1201.</ref><ref name="Shannon, M. P. 1994. pp. 80-93">Shannon, M. P., Lonigan, C. J., Finch, A. J. and Taylor, C. M. 1994. Children exposed to disaster: I. Epidemiology of post-traumatic symptoms and symptom profiles. ''Journal of American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry'', Vol. 33, pp. 80-93.</ref> However, rates of PTSD for children living in chronic conflict conditions varies from 15 to 50 per cent<ref>De Jong, J. T. V. M. 2002. ''Trauma, War, and Violence: Public Mental Health in Socio Cultural Context''. New York, Kluwer.</ref> as evidenced in the following countries: [[Iran]], [[Iraq]], [[Israel]], [[Kuwait]], [[Lebanon]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Rwanda]], [[South Africa]], and [[Sudan]].<ref name="Dyregrov, Gjestad & Raundalen 2002, pp. 59-68">{{cite journal |last=Dyregrov |first=A. |last2=Gjestad |first2=R. |last3=Raundalen |first3=M. |year=2002 |title=Children exposed to warfare: a longitudinal study |journal=Journal Trauma Stress |volume=15 |pages=59-68}}</ref><ref name="Thabet, Abed & Vostanis 2002, pp. 1801-1804">{{cite journal| last=Thabet |first=A.A. |last2=Abed |first2=Y. |last3=Vostanis |first3=P. |year=2002 |title=Emotional problems in Palestinian children living in a war zone: a cross-sectional study |journal=Lancet |volume=359 |pages=1801-1804}}</ref><ref>El-Khosondar, I. 2004. The Effect of Rational Behavior Therapy in Reducing the Effect of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder among Palestinian Children. Unpublished doctoral dissertation, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt.</ref><ref>Hawajri, A. 2003. Effectiveness of a Suggested Counseling Program to Alleviate Trauma among the Students of Basic Stage in Gaza Governorate. Unpublished master dissertation, Islamic University, Gaza, Palestine.</ref><ref>Mohlen, H., Parzer, P., Resch, F. and Brunner, R. 2005. Psychosocial support for war traumatized child and adolescent refugees: Evaluation of a short-term treatment program. Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry, Vol. 39 (1-2), pp. 81-87</ref><ref name="Husain 2005, pp. 239-246">{{cite book |last=Husain |first=S. |year=2005 |chapter=The experience of Bosnia-Herzegovina: Psychosocial consequences of war atrocities on children |editor-last=Lopez-Ibor |editor-first=J. |editor2-last=Christodoulou |editor2-first=G. |display-editors=et al |title=Disasters and Mental Health |location=New York |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |pages=239-246}}</ref><ref>Elbedour, S., Onwuegbuzie, A. J., Ghannamc, J., Whitcomed, J. A., Abu, H. F. 2007. Post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and anxiety among Gaza Strip adolescents in the wake of the second Uprising (Intifada). Child Abuse Neglect, Vol. 31, pp. 719-729.</ref><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125">One or more of the preceding sentences incorporates text from the [[free content]] work {{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002335/233558E.pdf|title=Investing against Evidence: The Global State of Early Childhood Care and Education |last=Marope |first=P.T.M. |last2=Kaga|first2=Y. |publisher=Paris, UNESCO |year=2015 |isbn=978-92-3-100113-0|location=|pages=118–125}}</ref>
== Impact of emergency and conflict experiences == In sum, emergency and conflict may impact on [[Child development|children’s development]] in the following manner: * Physical: exacerbation of medical problems, [[headache]]s, fatigue, unexplained physical complaints. * Cognitive: trouble concentrating, preoccupation with the traumatic event, recurring [[dream]]s or [[nightmare]]s, questioning spiritual beliefs, inability to process the event. * Emotional: [[Depression (mood)|depression]] or sadness, irritability, anger, resentfulness, despair, hopelessness, feelings of guilt, phobias, health concerns, [[anxiety]] or fearfulness. * Social: increased conflicts with family and friends, sleep problems, crying, changes in appetite, social withdrawal, talking repeatedly about the traumatic event, refusal to go to school, repetitive play.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
=== Impact on pregnancy === Research shows that environmental factors and experiences can alter the [[genetic make-up]] of a developing child.<ref name="Das, Hampton & Jirtle 2009, p, 563">{{cite journal |last=Das |first=R. |last2=Hampton |first2=D. D. |last3=Jirtle |first3=R.L. |year=2009 |title=Imprinting evolution and human health |journal=Mammalian Genome |volume=20 |number=10 |page= 563}}</ref> Exposure to prolonged stress, environmental [[toxin]]s or nutritional deficits chemically alter genes in the [[foetus]] or young child and may shape the individual’s development temporarily or permanently. Violence and maternal depression may also impair child development and mental health.<ref>Walker, S. P., Wachs, T. D. et al. 2007. Child development: risk factors for adverse outcomes in developing countries. ''The Lancet'', Vol. 369(9556), pp. 145-157.</ref> When trauma occurs at critical times of development for the foetus or young child, the impact on specialized cells for organs such as the [[brain]], [[heart]], or [[kidney]] can result in underdevelopment with lifetime implications for physical and mental health.<ref name="Das, Hampton & Jirtle 2009, p, 563" /> For instance, a study on Iraq showed the rate of [[heart defects]] at birth in [[Fallujah]] to be 13 times the rate found in [[Europe]]. And for birth defects involving the nervous system the rate was calculated to be 33 times that found in Europe for the same number of births.<ref>Alaani, S., Adsfahani, M. S., Tafash, M., and Manduca, P. 2008. Four polygamous families with congenital birth defects from Fallujah, Iraq. In Save the Children, Protecting Children in a Time of Crisis. Annual Report.</ref> Prolonged stress during pregnancy or early childhood can be particularly toxic and, in the absence of protective relationships, may also result in permanent genetic changes in developing brain cells. Evidence has shown that toxins and stress from the mother cross the [[placenta]] into the [[umbilical cord]],<ref>Balakrishnan, B., Henare, K., Thorstensen, E. B., Ponnampalam, A. P., Mitchell DPhil, M. D. 2010. Transfer of bisphenol A across the human placenta. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Vol. 202, pp. 393-395.</ref> leading to [[Premature birth|premature]] and low birth weight babies.<ref>Shonkoff, J. P., Boyce, W. T. and McEwen, B. S. 2009. Neuroscience, molecular biology, and the childhood roots of health disparities: Building a new framework for health promotion and disease prevention. JAMA, Vol. 301(21), pp. 2252-2259.</ref> Likewise, conflict trauma can affect pregnant women and the subsequent emotional health of their children.<ref name="Engel, Berkowitz, Wold & Yehuda 2005, pp. 334-341">{{cite journal |last=Engel |first=S.M. |first2=G.S. |last2=Berkowitz |last3=Wolf |first3=M. |last4=Yehuda |first4=R. |year=2005 |title=Psychological trauma associated with the World Trade Center attacks and its effect on pregnancy outcome |journal=Pediatric Prenatal Epidemiology |volume=19 |number=5 |pages=334-341}}</ref> In addition, babies of severely stressed and worried mothers are at higher risk to be born small or prematurely.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
=== Impact on child development === Children’s reactions to emergencies fluctuate depending on age, temperament, genetics, pre-existing problems, coping skills and cognitive competencies, and the dose of the emergency. Although most children are said to recover over time, if emergency reactions are left untreated, they can have a significant adverse impact on children’s social, emotional, behavioural and physical development.<ref>Zubenko, W. N. and Capozzoli, J. 2002. Children in Disasters: A Practical Guide to Healing and Recovery, New York, Oxford University Press.</ref><ref name="Dyregrov, Gjestad & Raundalen 2002, pp. 59-68" /><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
==== Age 6 and younger ==== In conflict-affected countries, the average mortality rate for children under 5 is more than double the rate in other countries. On the average, twelve children out of a hundred die before their fth birthday, compared with six out of a hundred.<ref name="UNESCO 2011">{{cite web |author=UNESCO |year=2011 |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0019/001907/190743e.pdf |title=EFA Global Monitoring Report: The Hidden Crisis - Armed Conflict and Education |location=Paris |publisher=UNESCO}}</ref> Common reactions among this age group are severe separation distress, crying, clinging, immobility and/or aimless motion, whimpering, screaming, sleeping and eating disorders, nightmares, fearfulness, regressive behaviours such as [[Thumb sucking|thumb-sucking]], [[Bed-Wetting|bed-wetting]], loss of bowel/bladder control, inability to dress or eat without assistance, and [[Fear of the dark|fear of darkness]], crowds and being left alone.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
During an investigation of the relationship between exposure to day raids and shelling and behavioural and emotional problems among Palestinian children, aged 3–6, in the [[Gaza Strip]], children demonstrated sleeping problems, poor concentration, attention-seeking behaviour, dependency, [[temper tantrums]] and increased fear.<ref name="Thabet, Abed & Vostanis 2002, pp. 1801-1804" /> Mothers of Palestinian kindergarten children reported severely impaired psychosocial and emotional functioning in their children.<ref>Massad, S., Nieto, F. J., [[Mari Palta|Palta, M.]], Smith, M., Clark, R., Thabet, A., 2009. Mental health of Palestinian children in kindergartens: Resilience and vulnerability. ''Child and Adolescent Mental Health'', Vol. 14(2), pp. 89-96, {{doi|10.1111/j.1475-3588.2009.00528.x}}.</ref> Thabet et al.<ref>Thabet, A. A., Vostanis, P. and Karim, K. 2005. Group crisis intervention for children during ongoing war conflict. ''Psychiatry'', Vol.14, pp. 262-269.</ref> examined the behavioural and emotional problems of 309 Palestinian [[Preschool|pre-schoolers]], and found that direct and indirect exposure to war trauma increased the risk of poor mental health. Zahr et al.,<ref>Zahr, L. K. 1996. Effects of war on the behavior of Lebanese pre-school children: The influence of home environment and family functioning. ''American Journal of Orthopsychiatry'', Vol. 66, pp. 401-408.</ref> in a study on the effect of war on Lebanese pre-school children, found more problems in children aged 3–6 years exposed to heavy shelling over a 2-year period than in a control group living without this threat. According to Yaktine,<ref>Yaktine, U. 1978. Effect of war on Lebanese children: New trends in children’s culture. ''The Arabic Cultural Club'', 119-121. (Arabic language)</ref> 40 mothers of different socio-economic backgrounds during the civil war in [[Beirut]] reported that their pre-school children became more anxious and fearful about bombardments and explosions. After [[SCUD missile|Scud missile]] attacks, displaced Israeli pre-school children demonstrated aggression, hyperactivity and oppositional behaviour and stress. This was compared with non-displaced children and, despite a continuous decrease in symptom severity, risk factors identified shortly after the [[Gulf War]] continued to exert their influence on children five years after the traumatic exposure.<ref>Laor, N., Wolmer, L., Cohen, D. J. 2001. Mothers’ functioning and children’s symptoms 5 years after a SCUD missile attack. ''American Journal of Psychiatry'', Vol. 158, No. 7, pp. 1020-1026.</ref><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
==== Ages 6 to 11 ==== Common symptoms in this age bracket include disturbing thoughts and images, nightmares, eating and sleeping disorders, noncompliance, irritability, extreme withdrawal, outbursts of anger and fighting, disruptive behaviour, inability to pay attention, irrational fears, regressive behaviour, depression and anxiety, feeling of guilt and emotional numbing, excessive clinging, headaches, [[nausea]] and visual or hearing problems. Traumatic events experienced before the age of 11 are three times more likely to result in serious emotional and behavioural difficulties than those experienced later in life.<ref>Goodman, G. S., Batterman-Faunce, J. M., Schaaf, J. M., and Kenney, R. 2002. Nearly 4 years after an event: Children’s eyewitness memory and adults’ perceptions of children’s accuracy. ''Child Abuse and Neglect'', Vol. 26(8), pp. 849-884.</ref> According to the Palestinian Counseling Centre, [[Save the Children International|Save the Children]], even six months after the demolition of their homes, young Palestinian children suffered from withdrawal, somatic complaints, depression/anxiety, unexplained pain, breathing problems, attention difficulties and violent behaviour. They were afraid to go to school, had problems relating to other children and greater attachment to caregivers. As a result, parents reported deterioration in educational achievement and ability to study.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" /> Al-Amine and Liabre <ref>Al Amine, A. and Llabre, M. 2008. The psychological conditions of children and youth in Lebanon after July 2006 War. ''Lebanese Association for Educational Studies, Kuwait Society for the Advancement of Arab Children''.</ref> revealed that 27.7 per cent of Lebanese children aged between 6 and 12 suffered from symptoms of PTSD, as well as from problems sleeping, agitation, difficulties in concentrating and excessive awareness of events related to the 2006 [[2006 Lebanon War|Lebanese-Israeli war]]. Many children in Sudan and northern [[Uganda]] who were forced to witness family members being [[torture]]d and murdered<ref name=":0" /> exhibited [[Stunted growth|stunting]], PTSD and other trauma-related disorders.<ref name="Husain 2005, pp. 239-246" />
=== Disabilities === Children with [[Disability|disabilities]] are disproportionately affected by emergencies, and many become disabled during disasters. Children with disabilities may suffer due to loss of their assistive devices, loss of access to medicines or rehabilitative services and, in some cases, loss of their caregiver. In addition, disabled children tend to be more vulnerable to abuse and violence. [[UNICEF]] research indicates that violence against children with disabilities occurs at annual rates at least 1.7 times greater than their able-bodied peers.<ref>UNICEF, 2005. ''Violence against Children with Disabilities: UN Secretary General’s Study on Violence against Children''. New York, UNICEF.</ref> Young children with disabilities living in conflict are more vulnerable and the consequent physical, psychological or emotional problems are higher. They are also more likely to develop emotional and mental health problems during emergencies because of lack of mobility, treatment, and medication or through starvation.<ref>Miles, S. and Medi, E. 1994. Community based support for disabled children in post-war Mozambique. ''Disasters'', Vol. 18, pp. 284-291.</ref> The [[Inter-Agency Standing Committee]] (IASC) recognizes that children with pre-existing disabilities are more vulnerable to mistreatment, [[discrimination]], abuse and [[destitution]].<ref name="IASC 2007">{{cite web |author=Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC)|year=2007 |title=IASC Guidelines on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergency Settings |url=http://www.who.int/mental_health/emergencies/guidelines_iasc_mental_health_psychosocial_june_2007.pdf}}</ref> Children with mobility, visual and hearing disabilities or intellectual impairments may feel particularly vulnerable if an emergency leads to the relocation of school and the learning of new daily routines. During emergencies, long unsafe distances to school, the lack of buildings with adequate facilities and equipment and teachers with minimum qualifications, are likely to be overwhelming challenges for young children with disabilities to be enrolled in day care and [[Early childhood education|early education]].<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
=== Gender differences === Some research shows that girls exhibit higher levels of distress than boys in relation to stressful situations and are considered at higher risk in situations of war and terror.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" /> Other research has found that girls express more worry,<ref>Lengua, L. J., Long, A. C., Smith, K. I., and Meltzo, A. N. 2005. Pre-attack symptomatology and temperament as predictors of children’s responses to the September 11 terrorist attacks. ''Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry'', Vol. 46, pp. 631-645.</ref> anxiety and depressive disorders,<ref>Hoven, C. W., Duarte, C. S., Lucas, C. P., Wu, P., Mandell, D. J., Goodwin, R. D., et.al. 2005. Psychopathology among New York City public school children 6 months after September 11. ''Archives General Psychiatry'', Vol. 6, pp. 545-552.</ref> and PTSD symptoms<ref>Green, B., Korol, M., Lindy, J., Gleser, G., and Kramer, L. A. 1991. Children and disaster: age, gender, and parental e ects on PTSD symptoms. ''Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry'', Vol. 30, pp. 945-951.</ref><ref name="Shannon, M. P. 1994. pp. 80-93"/> while boys show more behavioural problems in the aftermath of a disaster.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" /> However, pre-school girls exposed to [[earthquake]]s in [[Sultandağı|Sultandagi]] (Turkey) displayed more problematic behaviours than boys in the same educational category.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" /> Additionally, Wiest, Mocellin, and Motsisi<ref>Wiest, R. D., Mocellin, J. and Thandiwe Motsisi, D. 1992. ''The Needs of Women and Children in Emergencies''. Winnipeg, University of Manitoba.</ref> contend that young children, especially girls, may be vulnerable to [[sexual abuse]] and exploitation. Garbarino and Kostelny<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" /> reported that Palestinian boys suffered more than girls from psychological problems when exposed to chronic conflict. In another study, Palestinian boys were more susceptible to effects of violence during early childhood and girls during [[adolescence]].<ref>Leavitt, L. A. and Fox, N. A. 1993. ''Psychological Effects of War and Violence on Children''. Hillsdale, NJ, Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.</ref> In general it appears that boys take longer to recover, displaying more aggressive, antisocial and violent behaviour while girls may be more distressed but are more verbally expressive about their emotions.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
=== Educational consequences === In all conflict-affected countries, 21.5 million children of primary school age are out of school. Over the past decade, the problem of out-of- school children has been increasingly concentrated in conflict-affected countries, where the proportion increased from 29% in 2000 to 35% in 2014; in Northern Africa and Western Asia, it increased from 63% to 91%.<ref>One or more of the preceding sentences incorporates text from the [[free content]] work {{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002460/246045e.pdf|title=Creating sustainable futures for all; Global education monitoring report, 2016; Gender review|last=UNESCO|first=|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=20}}</ref>
Quality education alleviates the psychosocial impact of conflict and disasters by giving a sense of normalcy, stability, structure and hope for the future. However, emergency and conflict situations often undermine the quality of educational services. They result in shortages of materials, resources and personnel, thereby depriving young children of the opportunity to receive quality early education. In most conflicts, education infrastructure is usually a target. Pre-schools and schools are often destroyed or closed due to hazardous conditions depriving young children of the opportunity to learn and socialize in a safe place that provides a sense of routine.<ref name="UNICEF 2009">{{cite book |author=UNICEF |year=2009 |title=Children and Conflict in a Changing World: Machel Study 10-Year Strategic Review |location=New York |publisher=UNICEF}}</ref><ref>Obel, C. 2003. ''Epidemiological Studies of Stress during Pregnancy and Fetal Brain Development''. Arhus, Denmark, University of Aarhus.</ref><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
Young children living under emergencies are less likely to be in primary school and more likely to drop out. Primary school completion in poorer conflict-affected countries is 65 per cent while it is 86 per cent in other poor countries.<ref name="UNESCO 2011" /> According to the 2000 UNICEF MICS report, information from Iraq, for example, confirms the lack of Early Childhood Development programmes within the formal educational system. Only 3.7 per cent of children aged from 36 to 59 months were enrolled in nurseries or kindergartens. Low enrollment rates in early education programmes decrease the opportunity for young children to find a safe space where they flourish and release the stress and tension resulting from the emergency. In countries with ongoing emergencies, researchers have found a full range of symptoms that may be co-morbid with trauma, including [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]], poor academic performance, behavioural problems, [[bullying]] and abuse, [[oppositional defiant disorder]], conduct disorder, phobic disorder and negative relationships (Terr, 1991; Streeck-Fischer and van der Kolk, 2000).<ref>Terr, L. 1991. Childhood traumas: An outline and overview. ''American Journal of Psychiatry''. Vol.148, pp. 10-20.</ref><ref>Streeck-Fischer, A. and van der Kolk, B. A. 2009. Down will come baby, cradle and all: Diagnostic and therapeutic implications of chronic trauma on child development. ''Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry'', Vol. 34, pp. 903-918.</ref><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
A study using the Young Lives data in [[Ethiopia]] found that young children whose mothers had died were 20 per cent less likely to enroll in school, 21 per cent less likely to be able to write, and 27 per cent less likely to be able to read.<ref>Himaz, Rozana.2009. ''The Impact of Parental Death on Schooling and Subjective Well-being''. Young Lives Working Paper No. 44. <nowiki>http://www.younglives.org</nowiki>. uk/pdf/publication-sectionpdfs/ working-paper pdfs/WP44_Summary.pdf</ref> Dybdahl<ref>Dybdahl, R. 2001. Children and mothers in war: An outcome study of a psychosocial intervention program. ''Child Development''. Vol. 72 (4), pp. 1214-1230.</ref> found that 5- to 6-year-old war-traumatized [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian]] children showed lower levels of cognitive competence. Pre-school and school age Palestinian children exposed to severe losses, wounding and home destruction suffered impaired cognitive capacity for attention and concentration.<ref>Qouta, S., Punamaki, R.L. and El Sarraj, E. 2005. Mother-child expression of psychological distress in acute war trauma. ''Clinical Child Psychology and Psychiatry'', 2005, Vol. 10, pp. 135-156.</ref> Severe trauma has been found to be associated with in exible and narrowed attention and problem-solving strategies.<ref>Quota, S., Punamäki, R. L., and El Sarraj, E. 2008. Child development and family mental health in war and military violence: the Palestinian experience. ''International Journal of Behavioral Development'', Vol. 32 (4), pp. 310-321.</ref> Since both physical and mental health are linked to [[Language development|language]] and cognitive development,<ref name="Engel, Berkowitz, Wold & Yehuda 2005, pp. 334-341" /> it is reasonable to assume that violent conflict has a negative effect on these areas of development.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
== Supporting young children during emergency and conflict situations == Early childhood care and education (ECCE) is a multisectoral field that holistically addresses children’s multiple needs. During emergencies ECCE supportive services may address a range of issues including [[prenatal care]], [[immunization]], nutrition, education, psychosocial support and community engagement. Coordinated services of health and nutrition, [[Water, Sanitation and Hygiene|water sanitation and hygiene]], early learning, mental health and protection are considered essential in supporting young children living under emergencies and conflicts.<ref name="UNICEF 2009" /><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
Many programmes and strategies, whether in the formal or [[Non formal education|non-formal education]] sector, have proved to be very supportive to the well-being and recovery of young children living in areas of conflict. [[Child Friendly Spaces]] (CFS) programmes have been found valuable in creating a sense of normality and providing coping skills and resilience to children affected by emergencies.<ref name="CCF 2008">{{cite book |author=Christian Children’s Fund |year=2008 |title=Child-Centred Spaces Manual |location=Richmond |publisher=Christian Children’s Fund}}</ref><ref name="IASC 2007" /><ref>{{cite book |author=Inter-Agency Network for Education in Emergencies (INEE) |year=2004 |title=INEE Minimum Standards for Education in Emergencies, Chronic Crises and Early Reconstruction |location=Paris |publisher=INEE}}</ref> Child Friendly Spaces help children develop social skills and competencies such as sharing and cooperation through interaction with other children. They also offer opportunities to learn about risks in their environment and build life skills, such as [[literacy]] and non-violent conflict resolution, and provide a useful means of mobilizing communities around children’s needs. In an effort to strengthen community systems of [[child protection]], [[Christian Children's Fund]] (CCF)<ref name="CCF 2008" /> established three centres for internally displaced young children in Unyama (Uganda) camp that provided a safe, adult-supervised place for young children between 3 and 6 years of age. [[War Child (charity)|War Child]] established six ‘safe spaces’ in schools in northern Lebanon for displaced [[Syrians|Syrian]] children where counsellors used [[Art therapy|art]] and [[music therapy]] to help young children express their emotions in a healthy way.<ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />
Several studies show that children who have participated in quality education programmes within schools tend to have better knowledge of hazards, reduced levels of fear and more realistic risk perceptions than their peers.<ref>Llewellyn, D. 2010. ''Early Childhood Development Centre Curriculum Guide for Plan Indonesia''.</ref> In such contexts, psychosocial intervention programmes for young children and their families are considered to be vital. Interventions such as [[storytelling]], [[singing]], [[jumping rope]], role-play activities, team sports and writing and drawing exercises helped to reduce psychological distress associated with exposure to conflict-related violence in [[Sierra Leone]] for children aged 8 to 18.<ref name="Gupta & Zimmer 2008, pp. 212-216">{{cite journal|last=Gupta |first=L. |last2=Zimmer |first2=C. |year=2008 |title=Psychosocial intervention for war affected children in Sierra Leone |journal=British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=192 |number=3 |pages=212-216}}</ref> Studies in [[Eritrea]] and Sierra Leone revealed that children’s psychosocial well-being was improved by well-designed educational interventions.<ref name="Gupta & Zimmer 2008, pp. 212-216" /> In [[Afghanistan]], young children and adolescents gained a sense of stability and security after their involvement in constructive activities (e.g. art, narrative, sports) which took place in neutral safe places within their communities.<ref>Dawes, A. and Flisher, A. 2009. Children’s mental health in Afghanistan. ''Lancet'', Vol. 347 (9692), pp. 766-767.</ref><ref name="Marope & Kaga 2015, pp. 118–125" />

{{for|the play|Chimerica (play)}} [[Image:China USA Locator.svg|right|300px]] '''Chimerica''' is a [[neologism]] and [[portmanteau]] coined by [[Niall Ferguson]] and Moritz Schularick describing the [[symbiotic relationship]] between [[China]] and the [[United States]], with incidental reference to the legendary [[chimera (mythology)|chimera]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jfki.fu-berlin.de/faculty/economics/team/persons/schularick/chimerica.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613083353/http://www.jfki.fu-berlin.de/faculty/economics/team/persons/schularick/Chimerica.pdf |archivedate=2010-06-13 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/economistsforum/2009/02/how-china-helped-create-the-macroeconomic-backdrop-for-financial-crisis/|title=How China helped create the macroeconomic backdrop for financial crisis|date=February 24, 2009|work=Financial Times|author=Moritz Schularick}} {{subscription needed}}</ref><ref>[https://www.ft.com/search?q=chimerica chimerica search results] on ''[[Financial Times]]''</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/16/AR2008111601736.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Niall | last=Ferguson | title=Team 'Chimerica' | date=2008-11-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nathan-gardels/niall-ferguson-is-us-chin_b_245470.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Nathan | last=Gardels | title=Niall Ferguson: Is U.S.-China Economic Marriage on the Rocks? | date=2009-08-27}}</ref> Though the term is largely in reference to economics, there is also a political element.
==Origin== Historian Niall Ferguson and economist Moritz Schularick first coined the term in late 2006, arguing that [[global savings glut|saving]] by the Chinese and overspending by Americans led to an incredible period of wealth creation that contributed to the [[financial crisis of 2007–08]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/5424112/The-trillion-dollar-question-China-or-America.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Niall |last=Ferguson |title=The trillion dollar question: China or America? |date=2009-06-01}}</ref> For years, China accumulated large [[currency reserves]] and channeled them into US [[government securities]], which kept nominal and real long-term [[interest rates]] artificially low in the United States. Ferguson describes Chimerica as one economy which "accounts for around 13 percent of the world's [[land surface]], a quarter of its [[population]], about a third of its [[gross domestic product]], and somewhere over half of the global [[economic growth]] of the past six years."<ref name="American interest">{{cite web |url=http://www.the-american-interest.com/article.cfm?piece=533 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721015335/http://www.the-american-interest.com/article.cfm?piece=533 |archivedate=2009-07-21 |df= }}</ref> He suggests Chimerica could end if China were to decouple from the United States bringing with it a shift in [[global power]] and allowing China "to explore other spheres of global influence, from the [[Shanghai Cooperation Organization]], of which Russia is also a member, to its own informal nascent empire in commodity-rich Africa."<ref name="American interest" />
The accumulation of American debt, which has been estimated at over $800 billion, suggests the two nations are intrinsically linked; the economic symbiosis prevalent between the two suggests that separation would harm both countries and be disastrous for the global economy.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Another way to measure this integration is the trade deficit. The US trade deficit with China was $295 billion in 2011, meaning the US imported that much more goods and services from China than it exported to China. The [[Economic Policy Institute]] estimated that from 2001–2011, 2.7 million US jobs were lost to China.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/23/us-usa-china-trade-idUSBRE87M0T420120823 "U.S. trade gap with China cost 2.7 million jobs"], Reuters, August 23, 2012</ref>
The idea of Chimerica features prominently in Ferguson's 2008 book and adapted television documentary ''[[The Ascent of Money]]'', which reviews the history of money, credit, and banking.
The concept of Chimerica supplements and/or supplants ''[[Nichibei]]'', or the similarly constructed Japan-U.S. economic model and relationship that had been prominent in years before the development of Chimerica.

This is a chronicle of important events that took place under the [[Shunzhi Emperor]] of the [[Qing Dynasty]] (1636–1912) in what is now [[China]]. It spans from the death of his predecessor [[Hong Taiji]] (r. 1626–1643) in September 1643, to the emperor's own death on 5 February 1661, seven days into the eighteenth year of the Shunzhi [[Chinese era name|reign period]]. These dates do not correspond perfectly with the Shunzhi era itself, which started on 8 February 1644—on [[Chinese New Year|New Year's Day]] of the [[lunisolar calendar|lunisolar year]] following the emperor's accession—and ended on 17 February 1662 (the last day of the 18th year of Shunzhi), more than one [[solar year]] after the emperor's death. The posthumous events related to the Shunzhi Emperor's burial and posthumous cult are also included.
==Dorgon regency== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1643=== *'''September 21''': [[Hong Taiji]] dies after a successful seventeen-year reign during which the [[Qing]] became a major power in northeast Asia.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxnam|1975}} (p. 38), {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}} (p. 297), and {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 51) all place Hong Taiji's death on September 21 (Chongde 崇德 8.8.9). {{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}} (p. 74) gives the date as September 9.</ref> His death threatens to split the Manchus just as they are preparing to attack the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=74}}.</ref> *'''September 26''': a [[Deliberative Council]] of princes and high officials is convened and decides that five-year-old Fulin, [[Hong Taiji]]'s ninth son, will succeed his father, but that Hong Taiji's half-brother [[Dorgon]] and [[Jirgalang]] will be his co-regents. This deal is a compromise between those who wanted to keep the throne in Hung Taiji's descent (the main candidate was Hong Taiji's eldest son [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]]) and those who supported Dorgon. *'''October 8''': at the age of six ''sui'', [[Fulin]] officially becomes [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Qing dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=255}}.</ref>
===1644=== *'''February 8''': in [[Xi'an]], [[Li Zicheng]] founds the "[[Shun Dynasty|Great Shun]]" dynasty and proclaims himself King. *'''February 17''': [[Jirgalang]] willingly yields control of all official matters to his co-regent [[Dorgon]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=299}}.</ref> *'''March 5''': Dorgon sends an amicable letter to Li Zicheng proposing that they "devise a plan in common to unite their forces" against the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=304}}.</ref> *'''March 17''': the Shun army occupies [[Taiyuan]] in [[Shanxi]]. *'''April 5''': Seeing the progress of rebel armies in north China, the Chongzhen Emperor issues a call for the immediate help of any military commandant in the empire.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=641}}.</ref> *'''April 24''': Li Zicheng enters [[Beijing]], the capital of the [[Ming dynasty|Ming empire]]. *'''April 25''': the [[Chongzhen Emperor]] commits suicide on a hill behind the [[Forbidden City]]. *'''April 26''': [[Wu Sangui]], a powerful Ming general, moves his army through [[Shanhai Pass]] (at the eastern end of the [[Great Wall]]) and marches toward Beijing in response to the emperor's distress call. When he hears that the capital has fallen, Wu returns to fortify Shanhai Pass.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=290}}.</ref> Wu's departure from the fortified city of [[Xingcheng|Ningyuan]], where [[Battle of Ningyuan|Ming armies had defeated]] Qing founder [[Nurhaci]] in 1626, leaves all territory outside the Great Wall under Qing control. *'''April 29''': the victorious Li Zicheng holds an audience with several thousand Ming officials outside the Donghua Gate of the Forbidden City. Assisted by his main [[Grand Secretary]] [[Niu Jinxing]] (牛金星), Li selected 92 officials to serve in the Shun government. The remaining literati are given over to Shun generals for punishment.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=277–79}}.</ref> *'''May 5''': Wu Sangui routs an army led by Tang Tong, which Li Zicheng had despatched to attack Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 296">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}.</ref> *'''May 10''': Tang Tong's defeated army returns toward Shanhai Pass with reinforcements, but is again defeated by Wu Sangui. Wu takes the city of Yongping (永平) on the road to Beijing.<ref name="Wakeman 296"/> *'''May 13''': words reach the Qing capital of Shengjing that Li Zicheng has been brutalizing former Ming officials and the population of Beijing. Grand Secretary Fan Wencheng uses these news to argue for a Qing intervention in China.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=304}}.</ref> Dorgon agrees to mount a military expedition to punish the rebels and occupy the Central Plains of China.<ref name="Wakeman 305">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=305}}.</ref> *'''May 14''': Dorgon leads the Qing "Grand Army" out of Shengjing and starts marching south toward the Great Wall.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> *'''May 18''': After the defeat of two of his armies a few days earlier, Li Zicheng decides to take Shanhai Pass himself: he leaves Beijing with an army of 60,000 troops.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}, note 212.</ref> *'''May 20''': two of Wu Sangui's lieutenants arrive at Dorgon's camp at the [[Liao River]] carrying a message from their master asking the Manchus to help Wu defeat Li Zicheng's bandits and restore the Ming dynasty in return for "great profits" (大利).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=297}} (date of arrival at the Manchus' camp) and 300–1 (content of the letter).</ref> Dorgon sends a letter back to Wu Sangui offering.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Later that day the Manchus hear for the first time that the Chongzhen emperor was dead.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Still on that day, but as a result of earlier plans, small groups of Qing troops start to cross the Great Wall to distribute written proclamations announcing that the Qing army will not harm the population and will only kill Li Zicheng's bandits.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=306–307}}.</ref> *'''May 25''': By that date, Li Zicheng's army was already camping in the outskirts of Shanhai Pass, near the Sha River a few kilometers west of the Shanhai Pass garrison; Wu Sangui sends his troops to confront him there.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=309}}.</ref> Dorgon receives a letter confirming that Wu Sangui has accepted to work for the Qing: he takes his army on a forced march toward Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 310">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=310}}.</ref> *'''May 26''': having covered more than 150 kilometers in 24 hours, Dorgon's troops settle eight kilometers away from the Pass to rest for a few hours. They are awoken at midnight to continue marching.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> *'''May 27''': [[Battle of Shanhai Pass]]. At dawn Dorgon's main army reaches the gates of Shanhaiguan, where Dorgon receives Wu Sangui's formal surrender.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> The armies deploy for battle: placed in the vanguard, Wu's troops are ordered to charge the Shun army, but they are unable to break the rebels' line and suffer heavy casualties. By the late afternoon, they are on the verge of defeat when a sandstorm starts blowing on the battlefield.<ref name="Wakeman 311">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311}}.</ref> Dorgon chooses this moment to intervene: galloping around Wu's right flank, Qing bannermen destroys Li's left wing.<ref name="Wakeman 311"/> The Shun army is defeated and retreats chaotically toward Yongping; thousands are massacred.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311–12}}.</ref> *'''May 28''': Li Zicheng retreats from Yongping toward Beijing.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}.</ref> Wu Sangui is named Prince Pingxi; his remaining troops shave their heads and join the Qing forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}, note 262.</ref> *'''May 31''': Li Zicheng reenters Beijing with his troops, which started to loot the capital.<ref name="Wakeman 313">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}}.</ref> *'''June 3''': as a "final gesture of defiance" after his decisive defeat at Shanhai Pass, Li Zicheng officially declares himself [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Great Shun at the Wuying dian 武英殿.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}} (citation and date); {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=74}} (Wuying dian).</ref> *'''June 4''': after 42 days in Beijing, Li Zicheng sets the imperial palaces on fire and abandons the capital to flee toward the west.<ref name="Wakeman 313"/> The Beijing population massacres rebels who had not fled; nearly two thousand are killed.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313–14}}.</ref> *'''June 5''': led by Dorgon, Qing troops are welcomed into the capital; the Beijing population is shocked because it was expecting Wu Sangui to bring back the Ming heir apparent.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=314–15}}.</ref> *'''June 7''': Dorgon issues special proclamations to officials around the capital, assuring them that if the local population accepts to cut their hair and to surrender, the officials will be allowed to stay at their post.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=416}}.</ref> (See June 25.) *'''June 25''': because peasant rebellions quickly erupted around the capital in reaction to the haircutting order of June 7, Dorgon issues an edict saying that people will be allowed to arrange their hair the way they want.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 420–422. {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=84}} gives the date as June 28.</ref> *'''July 14''': Dorgon declares Beijing (which he calls "Yanjing" 燕京) the new capital of the Qing.<ref>{{harvnb|Naquin|2000|p=289}} (gives the date as Shunzhi 1.6.11).</ref> [[Mukden]] (present-day Shenyang), which had been the Qing capital since 1634, is retained as a secondary capital.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=19}}.</ref> *'''July 29''': at the request of his superior, German [[Jesuit]] missionary [[Johann Adam Schall von Bell]] petitions the Qing throne, claiming that the Jesuit calendar is more accurate than the other ones available.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}, note 24.</ref> *'''October 19''': the six-year-old Emperor arrives in Beijing through the Zhengyang Gate, where he is welcomed by Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the Jesuit Johann Adam Schall von Bell is made Director of the Bureau of Astronomy (欽天監) after a test of the Jesuits' prediction for an eclipse on September 1 proved to be more accurate than those of the court's official astronomer.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 857–58, note 24.</ref> *'''November 8''': a formal ritual of imperial enthronement is held for Fulin, during which the merits of Dorgon as regent are compared to those of the [[Duke of Zhou]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 858 and 860.</ref> Dorgon's title is raised from "Prince Regent" to "Uncle Prince Regent" (Shufu shezheng wang 叔父攝政王), in which ''shufu'' (''ecike'' in Manchu) represents a rank higher than that of imperial prince.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 860–61, and p. 861, note 31.</ref> *'''November 11''': Hooge is reinstated to the status of [[Prince Su]]; Dorgon's brother Ajige is named Prince Ying; Jirgalang is demoted from "Prince Regent" to "Assistant Uncle Prince Regent" (Fu zheng shuwang 輔政叔王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=861}}.</ref>
===1645=== *'''January 20''': the court orders that land without owners be reclaimed and given to Bannermen (圈地). In fact even land that has owners and occupants is confiscated.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|pp=109–10}}.</ref> (Say more.) *'''June 16''': it is declared that all official documents will heretofore refer to Dorgon as "Imperial Uncle Prince Regent" (''Huang shufu shezheng wang'' 皇叔父攝政王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861"/> Court ceremonies are also reformed to elevate Dorgon's ritual position even higher.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=862}}.</ref> *'''June 17''': the Prince of Fu, who had been reigning as the "Hongguang Emperor" since June of the previous year, is captured near Nanjing by Qing forces led by [[Liu Liangzuo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=666}}.</ref> *'''July 8''': all people who submit to the Qing dynasty are ordered to shave their forehead and tie their hair into a queue.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=128}}.</ref> This "haircutting command" provokes widespread resistance among the Chinese population. *'''July 29''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is named Regent (or "Protector of the State" 監國).<ref name="Struve 1988 665">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=665}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=131}}.</ref> *'''August 18''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is proclaimed [[Emperor of China|emperor]] less than a month after arriving in Fuzhou.<ref name="Struve 1988 665"/><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=140}}.</ref> He will reign under the title of Longwu 隆武. *'''August 24''': fall of [[Jiading District|Jiading]] to the forces of [[Li Chengdong]], a former Ming general who was now serving the Qing; he orders a massacre of the entire population.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 658–59.</ref> *'''September 22''': Li Chengdong takes Songjiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=672}}.</ref> *'''October 9''': the city of [[Jiangyin]] falls to Qing armies led by [[Liu Liangzuo]] after a siege of 83 days. The entire population (about 100,000 victims) is massacred over the next two days.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1975|page=83}}.</ref>
===1646=== *'''September 29 and 30''': hearing that Qing troops were approaching, the court of the [[Zhu Yujian, Prince of Tang|Longwu Emperor]] leaves Yanping in western Fujian and tries to flee toward Ganzhou in Jiangxi.<ref name="Struve 676">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=676}}.</ref> *'''October 6''': a Qing contingent catches up with the fleeing Longwu Emperor and executes him summarily.<ref name="Struve 676"/> *'''October 17''' or '''27''': the Qing army captures Fuzhou unopposed.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988}} (p. 676) gives October 17; {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 171) has October 27 (Shunzhi 3.9.19).</ref> *'''November 19''': the Qing forbids officials to memorialize about five controversial issues: haircutting (剃髮), costume (衣冠), the seizure of lands (圈地), (投充), and runaway slaves (逃人).<ref name="Gong 2010 173">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=173}}.</ref> *'''November 20''': [[Zhu Youlang]], the Ming Prince of Gui, is named protector of the state (監國) in [[Zhaoqing]] (Guangdong); it is decided that he will reign under the title Yongli 永曆.<ref name="Gong 2010 173"/> *'''December 21''': [[Zheng Zhilong]], who had defended the [[Longwu]] court, surrenders to the Qing in Fuzhou. He is taken north as a prisoner.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=176}}.</ref>
===1647=== *'''February 1''': Bandit leader [[Zhang Xianzhong]] is killed in battle by Qing troops led by [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]], the son of Hong Taiji who had failed to succeed his father on the imperial throne in 1643.<ref>{{harvnb|Dai|2009}}, pp. 17–18.</ref> *'''August 2''': Dorgon's brother Dodo is named [[Dodo, Prince Yu|Prince Yu]].<ref name="Gong 2010 192">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=192}}.</ref> *'''September 7''': The Qing court forbids Portuguese merchants based in [[Macao]] from entering the provinces to trade.<ref name="Gong 2010 192"/> *'''September 28 / October 27''' (SZ4.9): the court receives an embassy sent by the Ryukyu king to congratulate the Shunzhi Emperor on his accession.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=194}}.</ref>
===1648=== *'''February 25''': Haoge (Prince Su) returns to the capital after his victorious but costly Sichuan campaign (see Feb. 1, 1647).<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=198}}.</ref> *'''March 29''': Dorgon demotes [[Jirgalang]] from Prince Zheng to Prince of the second rank (郡王).<ref name="Gong 2010 199">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=199}}.</ref> He was given back his rank on '''May 25'''.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=202}}.</ref> *'''April 5''': [[Names of Vietnam|Annam]] sends a tributary embassy to the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Gong 2010 199"/> *'''March 24 / April 22''' (SZ5.3): Milayin and Ding Guodong rise against the Qing in Gansu.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=200}}.</ref>
===1649=== *'''April 29''': [[Dodo, Prince Yu|prince Dodo]] (Dorgon's brother from the same mother) dies of [[smallpox]] in Beijing.<ref name="Dennerline 99">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=99}}.</ref> Dorgon's other [[uterine brother]] Ajige is placed in charge of managing the affairs of the capital.<ref name="Dennerline 99"/> *'''May 27''': [[Empress Xiaoduanwen|Empress Dowager Xiaoduanwen]], [[Hong Taiji]]'s former empress, dies.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ("[[Draft History of Qing]]"), ch. 214 ("Biographies of consorts" 后妃傳), p. 8901, where the exact date of death is recorded as the ''yisi'' 乙巳 day of the 4th month of the 6th year of Shunzhi.</ref> As a result, the Shunzhi emperor's mother [[Empress Dowager Xiaozhuang]] becomes the most powerful woman in the palace.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=135}}.</ref> *'''October 4''': Qing banner troops take back [[Datong]] (Shanxi) from the hands of rebellious commander Jiang Xiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=100}}.</ref> *'''December 30''': [[Geng Zhongming]] (耿仲明; 1604–1649) commits suicide in Jiangxi after being accused of protecting subordinates who had helped three hundred runaway slaves to hide from their masters.<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1017}}.</ref> His armies, now led by his son [[Geng Jimao]] (耿繼茂), nonetheless continue to fight the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017"/>
===1650=== *'''November 24''': After a long siege, Qing armies led by [[Shang Kexi]] capture [[Guangzhou|Canton]] and massacre its population.<ref name="Dennerline 101">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=101}}.</ref> Firmly entrenched in the south, Shang later became one of the [[Three Feudatories]]. *'''November 26''': [[Kong Youde]] 孔有德 (1602–1652) captures [[Guilin]] ([[Guangxi]]) for the Qing.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> *'''December 31''': Dorgon dies at the age of 38 during a hunting expedition.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> His death created an immediate backlash against his political allies at court.
==Transition and personal rule== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:CITE]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1651=== *'''January 26''': Dorgon's brother [[Ajige]] is imprisoned for allegedly plotting a coup after the death of Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 101–102.</ref> He was forced to commit suicide later that year.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=104}}.</ref> *'''April 7''': the Shunzhi Emperor issues an edict declaring his intention to root out corruption among officials.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=106}}.</ref> The anticorruption campaign that followed first targeted officials who had been close to Dorgon, but it soon led to a revival of factional politics among literati officials, a problem that plagued the young emperor until his death in 1661.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 106–107.</ref> *'''September''': the emperor marries a niece of his mother the Empress Dowager.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=929}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the monumental "Gate of Receiving Heaven" (Chengtian men 承天門) facing south from the imperial city is renamed "Gate of Heavenly Peace" ([[Tiananmen]] 天安門).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=928}}.</ref> *'''December 13''': Consort Ba 巴 gives birth to Niuniu 牛鈕, the Shunzhi emperor's first son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 127, Shunzhi 8.11.乙亥 (1st). The mother is named in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref>
===1652=== *'''March 9''': death of the emperor's first son Niuniu less than three months after his birth.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 128, Shunzhi 9.1.壬寅 (30th).</ref> *'''Spring''': in an edict to the [[Inner Three Courts]], the Shunzhi Emperor orders that all memorials concerning state matters should now be sent to him rather than to Jirgalang's office.<ref name="Lui 46">{{harvnb|Lui|1989|p=46}}.</ref> This marks the time when the monarch takes full charge of the government.<ref name="Lui 46"/> *'''August 7''': Southern Ming loyalist [[Li Dingguo]], an ancient lieutenant of bandit king [[Zhang Xianzhong]], retakes the key southwestern city of [[Guilin]] from the Qing; the Qing commander-in-chief Kong Youde commits suicide.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 972 (Kong commits suicide) and 973, note 194 (taking of Guilin by Li).</ref> Within a month, most of the [[Guangxi]] military commanders who had served the Qing reverted to the Ming side.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=973}}, note 194.</ref>
===1653=== *'''January 14''': the [[Fifth Dalai Lama]] arrives in Beijing to meet with the Shunzhi Emperor.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}; {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=258}} (the former cites the entry from the Qing ''Veritable Records'' indicating the date of the Dalai Lama's arrival).</ref> He leaves about two months later.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}.</ref> *'''April 25''': the emperor recalls [[Feng Quan]] 馮銓 to serve in the government again.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=954}}.</ref> That very evening he was summoned to meet with the emperor, [[Hong Chengchou]], and [[Chen Mingxia]] 陳名夏<ref>{{cite journal |last=Godley |first=Michael R. |last2= |first2= |date= |title=The End of the Queue: Hair as Symbol in Chinese History |url=http://www.chinaheritagequarterly.org/features.php?searchterm=027_queue.inc&issue=027 |journal=China Heritage Quarterly |publisher=The Australian National University |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref> to discuss the qualifications of [[Hanlin Academy]] compilers, who had been mostly appointed by Chen Mingxia, a southerner.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=956}}.</ref> Even though Shunzhi was trying to counteract the influence of southern Chinese officials who advocated a return to Ming government practices, by recalling a pro-Manchu collaborator like Feng Quan, he actually intensified the tensions between northern and southern Chinese literati.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=958}}.</ref> *'''July 23''': to counteract the power of the [[Imperial Household Department]], Shunzhi establishes the Thirteen Offices (内十三衙门), which are controlled by eunuchs.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=931}}. The exact date can be found in {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=266}}.</ref> These bureaus allowed eunuch power to grow;<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=257}}.</ref> they were eliminated by Oboi and the other regents at the beginning of the Kangxi reign. *'''September 8''': Consort Ningyi 寧懿 of the [[Donggo]] clan gives birth to [[Fuquan (prince)|Fuquan]], the emperor's second son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 135, Shunzhi 10.7.庚戌 (17th).</ref> He died in 1703.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.壬寅 (28th), or August 10, 1703.</ref> *'''December 15''': The court forbids actors (優人) from not shaving their hair on the pretext that they have to play female roles.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=267}}.</ref>
===1654=== *'''March 8''': [[Shang Kexi]] is appointed to govern 鎮 [[Guangdong]], whereas [[Geng Jimao]] is ordered to garrison [[Guilin]] and to take care of the Green Standard Armies that had been established by [[Kong Youde]].<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=269}}.</ref> *'''April 27''': on recommendation by the [[Deliberative Council of Princes and Ministers]] led by [[Jirgalang]], [[Chen Mingxia]] (陳名夏), who had been an influential [[Grand Secretary]], is executed by strangling after a ten-day trial for corruption that started when he proposed to restore the hairstyle and court costume of the Ming dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=985–86}}.</ref> *'''May 4''': [[Xiao Hui Zhang|Empress Xiaohui]] gives birth to the emperor third son [[Xuanye]] 玄燁 ([[Manchu language|Manchu]]: {{MongolUnicode|ᡥᡳᠣᠸᠠᠨ ᠶᡝᡳ}} Hiowan Yei), who later became the [[Kangxi Emperor]].
===1655=== *'''March 14''': Jirgalang asks the Emperor to establish an Imperial Diarist 起居注官 to keep a diary of the emperor's movements.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=270}}.</ref>
===1656=== *'''August 6''': The Qing forbids sea trade in the southeastern provinces. Private merchant ships are forbidden from trading and other ships from accosting.<ref name="Gong 2010 288">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=288}}.</ref> The purpose of this policy was to eliminate those among sea merchants who supported the Southern Ming power of [[Zheng Chenggong]].<ref name="Gong 2010 288"/>
===1657=== *'''November 5''': [[Empress Xiao Xian|Imperial Noble Consort Donggo]], the emperor's favorite consort, gives birth to the emperor's fourth son, who died before he was given a name (see February 25, 1658). *'''November 30''': the Shuntian examination cheating scandal erupts.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=295}}.</ref> *'''December 8''': the emperor's fifth son, [[Changning (prince)|Changning]], is born to Consort Chen 陳.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 150, Shunzhi 14.11.壬寅 (4th). The mother is named in ''Qingshigao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He became Prince Gong (恭親王) in 1671 and died in 1703.<ref>Date of his becoming prince: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 180, Kangxi 10.1.癸酉 (21st), i.e., 1 March 1671. Date of death: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.辛巳 (7th), i.e., 20 July 1703.</ref>
===1658=== *'''February 25''': death of the emperor's fourth son a little more than 100 days after his birth. He was posthumously granted the title of Prince Rong (榮親王).<ref>{{Harvnb|Li|2003|pp=594–95}}.</ref> *'''August 13''': the emperor changes the old Manchu Inner Three Courts into a "Palace Secretariat" (''diange'' 殿閣) and reinstitutes the old [[Hanlin Academy]], both based on old Ming institutions.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1007}}.</ref> Though these institutions were abrogated during the [[Oboi regency]] (1661–1669), the [[Kangxi Emperor]] reinstated them in 1670 (the former as the "Grand Secretariat," or ''neige'' 內閣) and they lasted until the end of the Qing in 1911.
===1659=== *'''January 25''': Qing forces led by prince Dodo's second son Doni enter the capital of Yunnan, sending the [[Yongli Emperor]] into flight to Burma under the protection of [[Li Dingguo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=117}}. {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}} gives the date as January 23.</ref> *'''March 7''': the core of the Southern Ming army is defeated at [[Dali City|Dali]], forcing the [[Yongli Emperor]], the last monarch of the southern Ming, to flee toward [[Burma]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}}.</ref>
===1660=== *'''January 3''': birth of the emperor's sixth son Qishou 奇授 (Manchu: Kišeo) to Consort Tang 唐.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 156, Shunzhi 16.11.戊寅 (21st). The mother is identified in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of seven [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910">''Qingshi gao'', ch. 214, p. 8910.</ref> *'''March 6''': to counter factional politics, the Shunzhi emperor issues an edict banning clubs or societies whose purpose was to influence government affairs or public opinion.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1982|p=258}}.</ref> *'''May 30''': Consort Niu gives birth to the emperor's seventh son, Longxi 隆禧 (Manchu: Lunghi).<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, pp. 158–59, Shunzhi 17.4.丙午 (22nd).</ref> He died in 1679.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 200, Kangxi 18.7.丁未 (15th), or August 20, 1679.</ref> *'''September 23''': death of the emperor's favorite concubine, "Imperial Consort of the Second Rank" Donggo.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|p=72}}.</ref> Jesuit missionary [[Adam Schall]], who had been close to the emperor in 1656 and 1657 and who attended the concubine's expensive funerals, later claimed that "Through her death she made [the emperor] fall into a madness more repulsive than the one of [[Solomon|Salomon]], because he openly displayed himself as a disciple of [[Sangha (Buddhism)|the Bonzes]], shaving his head, and living and dressing himself like them."<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008}} pp. 72 (in the words of Schall, "a very great Funeral" with many "wasteful ceremonies") and 74 (citation).</ref>
===1661=== *'''January 23''': birth of the emperor's eighth son, Yonggan, to Consort Muktu 穆克圖.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 161, Shunzhi 17.12.甲辰 (23rd). The mother is mentioned in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of eight [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910"/> *'''February 5''': the Shunzhi emperor dies of [[smallpox]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=118}}.</ref>
==After death== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1661=== *'''March 2''': in a lavish procession, the emperor's body is transported to Jingshan—north of the Forbidden City—where it stayed for about two years until the emperor was finally buried.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=74–75}}.</ref> On '''March 3''' a large number of precious goods are burned as offerings, after which the [[Kangxi Emperor|new emperor]] takes off his mourning dress.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=73–74}}.</ref> *'''April 22''': the dead emperor is given a [[temple name]] (Shizu 世祖)—by which he would be worshipped at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]]—and an honorific [[posthumous name]] (體天隆運定統建極英睿欽文顯武大德弘功至仁純孝章皇帝 ''Titian longyun dingtong jianji yingrui qinwen xianwu dade honggong zhiren chunxiao zhang huangdi'').<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], ch. 5, p. 163: Shunzhi 18.3.癸酉 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1662=== *'''January 13''': the ancestral tablets of the Shunzhi emperor are placed at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]], where he will be worshipped under the [[temple name]] Shizu.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 167. Date: Shunzhi 18.11.己亥 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1663=== *'''July 5 / August 2''' (KX2.6): the emperor's body is buried at the Xiaoling.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 169.</ref>
